newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: APEC edges away from endorsing U.S. info-tech plan.
newsitem.headline: APEC edges away from endorsing U.S. info-tech plan.

text.p: Asia-Pacific nations on Friday backed away from fully endorsing a U.S. plan to free global trade in computers and telecommunications at the turn of the century, officials and delegates said.

Washington had hoped the 18 members of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum would give a ringing endorsement to its plan to cut tariffs to zero by the year 2000 on a broad range of information technology products.

Instead, trade and foreign ministers, who began a two-day meeting ahead of a summit of Asia-Pacific leaders on Monday, will issue a vaguely worded statement welcoming the ongoing negotiations in Geneva on such a pact.

"We've worked out language that's acceptable," said a senior representative from a Latin American delegation. "It will say that efforts in Geneva to conclude an ITA (information Technology Agreement) are endorsed by APEC."
"But we don't want to prejudge the outcome in Geneva by having negotiations about it here (at APEC)," the delegate said.
The stakes are high. Washington says the information technology business is worth $1.8 trillion and the United States accounts for 60 percent of it.

The United States wanted APEC's full endorsement of the ITA to give the pact a head start at next month's inaugural World Trade Organisation meeting in Singapore, where it is to be formally submitted.

Japan's Trade Minister Shinji Sato told Reuters on Friday that while Tokyo and Washington were enthusiastic, "we should not push it too strongly here, because we might invite the suspicion of other members".
"If we emphasise this too strongly, then other countries are likely to start questioning what we are doing," Sato said.
Nevertheless, the United States remained optimistic about the pact's fate at APEC.
"I won't be able to give you box score right now because (negotiations) are going on even as we sit here," said Ambassador John Wolf, the American coordinator for APEC.
"But we're working and there's a lot of interest and we're going to continue working on it," he said.
The United States has offered to lower tariffs on various products in return for individual countries' support for ITA.
Malaysia and some other developing countries object to the tariff targets and timeframes in the pact, saying it undermines the essential volunteerism of the diverse group.
"I know we are under pressure over the ITA issue," a Japanese spokesman quoted Malaysian Minister of Trade and Industry Rafidah Aziz as saying after meeting Sato on Friday.
"But it is impossible for many countries to make a commitment to it today," Rafidah told Sato.
APEC decisions are based on consensus, which means crafting language that is acceptable to all members.
Rodolfo Severino, the undersecretary in the Philippine Foreign Ministry, told reporters the ministers would reach a consensus on the accord.
It "will probably be expressed" either in the statement following the conference of trade and foreign ministers or in the joint declaration after the leaders' summit, or both.
"I think that some formula will be arrived at with the approval of all ministers, which will take into account members' concerns," Severino said.

Gary Tooker, chief executive officer of Motorola Inc, said he was hopeful that the ITA would be endorsed by APEC. "If they hold back, I think it will be a disadvantage to the entire APEC process," said Tooker, speaking to Reuters at a meeting of business leaders running parallel to the APEC conference.
